ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CIVIL SERVICE
(Evaluation of staff performance)


    1. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Prime Minister whether a better system for evaluating staff performance will be used to facilitate the career development of officers in Division I grades in the civil service and what comparative studies have been made on the merits of different systems used locally and overseas to ensure that the best possible system is used

    14. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for Finance whether a better

Column: 809

system for evaluating staff performance will be used to facilitate the career development of officers in the various grades in the civil service and what comparative studies have been made on the merits of different systems used locally and overseas to ensure that the best possible system is used.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen) (for the Prime Minister): Sir, the Member for Kampong Kembangan has raised two questions (Nos. 1 and 14) pertaining to evaluation of staff performance, which are identical except that they are addressed correctly to different Ministers in accordance with their portfolio responsibilities. Since the answers required are mainly technical, it would perhaps be convenient for me to take and answer both questions together.

    The present system for evaluating staff performance is essentially based on confidential reporting by supervisory officers. In the case of confirmed officers, the reports are put up annually while for probationers, they are done six-monthly. The performance of an officer reported on is graded according to a number of attributes relevant to his work. Such an assessment is usually made by the officer's immediate supervisor and subject to a second opinion of a Countersigning Officer who is usually the superior of the Reporting Officer. Through this, a fairly reasonable assessment of the performance of an officer is made.

    However, the present Staff Confidential Report Form for Divisions I and II officers in the Civil Service is designed for the assessment of officers performing administrative and managerial duties. It does not provide a very accurate assessment of those in professional grades where the emphasis is on professional capabilities rather than on administrative skills.

    The Management Services Department of the Ministry of Finance has invited Permanent Secretaries and Heads of major Departments who have professional officers to make proposals on how the reporting system can be improved. These proposals will be considered by a Committee comprising representatives from the Prime

Column: 810

Minister's Office, the Public Service Commission and the Ministry of Finance.

    The Prime Minister's Office has also designed a staff report form for officers in the Administrative Service in which more attention is focussed on the officer's capability and suitability and which at the same time allows for their weaknesses to be specified so that remedial action can be taken. The revised format is presently being studied by the Public Service Commission.

    I should like to add that the efficacy of any system of performance evaluation will largely depend on the ability of officers entrusted with the task of making assessments to maintain objectivity in their assessments.

KALLANG BASIN
(Request for additional flats)


    2. Mr S. Dhanabalan asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether there are plans to construct more Housing and Development Board flats for rental in the Kallang Basin area, especially in the area known as Polling District III in the Kallang Electoral Constituency, as the Kallang Basin area is very popular among those wanting to rent HDB flats and has the largest number of applicants (2,277 as at 31st December, 1976) on the waiting list among all the HDB areas.

    The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of applicants on the waiting list for Kallang Basin covers three Electoral Constituencies; namely, Kallang. Geylang West and Kolam Aver.

    At present, 692 more units are under construction at Kolam Aver Constituency. Apart from this, the Board has no plans to build additional flats in the area known as Polling District III in the Kallang Constituency.

SERANGOON GARDEN WAY/CHENG SAN ROAD
(Measures to reduce earth spillage and traffic hazards)


    3. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether measures can be taken to minimize the dirt pollution and traffic hazards caused by lorries, transporting earth and other construction materials, travelling through Serangoon Garden Way and Cheng San Road to Ang Mo Kio housing estate and vice versa.

    The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the second quarter of 1976, the Housing and Development Board has stopped earth transportation by lorries to Ang Mo Kio New Town through Serangoon Garden Way. However, lorries carrying construction materials continue to use Serangoon Garden Way and Cheng San Road. Mud and dirt could have been brought out onto these roads by these lorries and other vehicles after driving through earth tracks and construction sites in Ang Mo Kio.

    The HDB has arranged for workers to sweep and clean the two roads regularly to reduce dust and dirt pollution. In addition, officers from the Ministry of the Environment and the Traffic Police will continue to take enforcement action against lorry drivers and contractors who load their lorries improperly and cause excessive spillage.

    To reduce hazards to other road users, the Traffic Police will also step up its enforcement against lorry drivers who speed or drive recklessly along Serangoon Garden Way and Cheng San Road. At the same time, the Registry of Vehicles has directed lorry operators to supervise their drivers closely and to avoid spillage from lorries.

    With these actions, dust pollution and traffic hazards caused by lorries will be minimised.

RADIO AND TELEVISION SINGAPORE
(Selection of articles and artistes)


    4. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for Culture and Science and Technology how Radio and Television Singapore select (i) the articles for its drama and comedy programmes, and (ii) the artistes and participants in its children's programmes.

    The Minister for Culture and Science and Technology (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, artistes and participants for RTS drama, comedy and children's programmes are drawn from a pool of artistes built up over the years. Selection of artistes for specific programmes is determined by such factors as the nature of the programme, suitability of artistes for certain roles, their experience and the standard of their performance. Artistes who do not keep up with their standard of performance are phased out or not used.

    The pool of artistes is constantly enlarged by: -

    (1) mass auditions which are normally conducted to find talent for a new series of programme;

    (2) the holding of contests, such as Talentime;

    (3) Periodic auditions which are held to ascertain the suitability of persons who write in indicating an interest in taking part in TV or Radio programmes;

    (4) talents who come to the notice of our staff through their performance at shows, dramas staged by cultural organisations.

    The Malay and Chinese services of Radio Singapore also each run a children's workshop which yearly recruits new members for training in acting, singing and compering. These children are then used in programmes produced by the services. The Indian service holds auditions twice a year for students to spot those with ability in music or drama.

    Artistes who take part in TV programmes in particular are required to spend a great deal of time in rehearsals and recordings.

Column: 813

Some find the monetary returns from RTS not attractive enough and they either stop or take up more paying assignments elsewhere. This does lead sometimes to a dependence on a smaller group of artistes than is desirable. Although fresh or new talents are discovered through auditions or contests, they need time to gain experience in order to take on more demanding roles in, say, a drama.

GOVERNMENT CRECHES
(Takeover by trade union)


    5. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Social Affairs how many Government creches have been taken over by a trade union and how many more will be taken over; and what are the reasons and conditions for the take over.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Encik Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, so far, only the Kallang Creche has been taken over by the Singapore Industrial Labour Organisation (SILO) with effect 1st October, 1976

    My Ministry has been discussing with the National Trades Union Congress on the proposal for the NTUC to take over the remaining 10 creches at present administered by the Social Welfare Department. This is in line with the Government's policy to encourage private and industrial organisations to operate creches to help working mothers. It is particularly appropriate that the NTUC should take a lead in this area as it is best placed to understand and appreciate the practical difficulties of employment. It is also in line with the NTUC's policy of looking after the welfare of workers.

    As for the conditions for the handover, these are still being discussed but basically the NTUC would be responsible for the day-to-day running of the creches on a financial subsidy given by the Government. The Social Welfare Department will continue to look after the hardship cases which are sent to the creches.

Column: 814



    It is planned for the NTUC to take over the creches by the end of this year on a phased schedule.

ISSUE OF HAWKER LICENCES TO CITIZENS AFFECTED BY RESETTLEMENT


    6. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Law and the Environment if he will consider issuing hawker licences to those citizens who are affected by resettlement.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for Law and the Environment)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, hawker licences are not issued to all citizens who are affected by resettlement undertaken by the Government. However, stalls in markets and food centres have been allotted to persons whose earnings are adversely affected by resettlement due to public projects undertaken by the Ministries or departments concerned, so that they can have a new way to make a living.

    Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary said that action has been taken to issue hawker licences to some, but not to all citizens who are affected by resettlement. Can the Parliamentary Secretary inform this House under what circumstances is allocation of stalls made, and so far how many of those who are affected by resettlement have been given hawker licences?

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Sir, in answer to the question concerning the circumstances leading to the allocation of hawker stalls, I would say that basically approval is given to those who are affected to the extent of losing their opportunity to earn a living, for example, fishermen or farmers who, as a result of resettlement, have lost their means of livelihood. Another circumstance could be that the compensation they get is not much and that they are still in financial difficulties, then consideration will be given for the allocation

Column: 815

of stalls to such people. On the other hand, hereafter we shall liberalise the issue of hawker licences for such people.

    As regards the number of cases of successful allocations, I have some figures here. In the whole year of 1976 168 resettlement cases have been allotted hawker stalls. But these hawker stalls are those built by the Ministry of the Environment, which are of the older type and are not popular, and only one farmer has accepted the offer. In the case of Jurong Town, seven have accepted the offers, whereas in the case of markets under the administration of the Housing and Development Board, 160 cases have accepted the offers. This is because in the Housing Board estates the markets are new and are all sited in population centres. Therefore, their stalls are more popular.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary has mentioned in his reply about liberalising the issue of hawker licences. I would like to ask him how is the issue of licences to be liberalised. Secondly, in the case of those affected by resettlement and suffer financial hardship to whom consideration would be given, I would like to ask who is to give such consideration?

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on the point raised by the Member for Jalan Kayu, I would say that consideration is given by a committee to those people who suffer financial hardship directly as a result of resettlement or who have lost their means of livelihood in the process of resettlement. There are now four departments in charge of hawkers, namely, the Ministry of the Environment, the Housing and Development Board, the Port of Singapore Authority and the Jurong Town Corporation. So this coordinating committee, in charge of mutual matters and common measures, will consider such cases.

    Mr Ngeow Pack Hua (Boon Lay)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, who really

Column: 816

considers the issue of licences? Is it the JTC or the Ministry of the Environment?

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is the committee which considers such cases. For example, if those affected are in JTC charge then, of course, the recommendation will come from the Resettlement Department of the JTC, and if those affected are in the Housing Board estates, then the recommendation will come from the Housing Board for consideration by the committee.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, who undertakes the investigation? I believe that up till now nobody from any of these departments is undertaking an investigation.

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on this question I have already stated that the department directly concerned is charged with the responsibility for the investigation. For example, if it concerns the Housing Board, then the Housing Board is responsible for the investigation. If it is the Ministry of the Environment, then that Ministry will take action to investigate the applications, and so on. As far as I am aware, apart from asking the applicants concerned to come for interview, we even carry out on-the-site investigation by calling on the applicants in their homes.

    Mr Lai Tha Chai (Henderson)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether consideration will be given to the removal of one of the conditions for the issue of licences, i.e, the applicant must be above 40 years old. To go a step further, is he aware that a person who is more than 60 years old and has only a daughter earning less than $100 to support the aged parents is also not eligible to apply at the moment?

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think it is because of our policy a few years ago to reduce the number of hawkers in Singapore that this age restriction was imposed. It does not necessarily mean that all hawkers must be above the age of

Column: 817

40. In fact, before 1973 a lot of hawkers were in the age group of 20 years and 30 years. However, in cases of difficult family circumstances, for example, the applicant is a widow, those who are disabled or who have medical certificates to show that they are unable to undertake laborious manual work, then special consideration will be given to their application for hawker licences. As I have said, we are now reviewing our policy with a view to liberalising the restrictions on hardship cases, especially in regard to age restriction and other factors. An over-all review of the position is being undertaken at the moment. I think in future the conditions will be more relaxed.

    Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Mr Speaker, Sir, is it our policy to progressively reduce the number of hawkers? If so, would it not be true to say that in the long run there will be no hawkers? What then will be the position of the hawkers?

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, as a long-term policy, we do not basically encourage roadside hawking. After 1973 we had ceased to issue any more licences for street hawking or roadside hawking. Hawker licences are only issued to those resettlement cases and they are accommodated in sheltered hawker centres. That has always been the policy of the Government because there are a lot of labour jobs without the people to take them. So it is our hope that our citizens will direct their energy to working in private enterprises, factories and other services.

    Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the present hawkers get older and with the stringent policy of limiting the transfer of licences to their children. I think we can anticipate that, in the long run, there will be no hawkers. Is it the objective of the Ministry that in the long run there will be no hawkers?

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, that is not our policy. In the long run, of course, we will still need the services of the hawkers. As regards the application by members of family for transfer of hawker

Column: 818

licences, we have to consider each case on its own merit. For instance, if a hawker licence is held by the father and his children have been helping him all this time, then in such a case, we normally allow the transfer of a licence from the father to a member of his family.

JURONG ROAD
(Speeding by earth-carrying lorries)


    7. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education what effective measures are being or will be taken to curb speeding by drivers of earth-carrying lorries along Jurong Road.

    The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, various measures have been taken to check and book drivers of earth-carrying lorries speeding along Jurong Road. These measures include the use of radar speed traps. patrols by the Traffic Mobile Squad and the use of unmarked pursuit cars. The Police is also studying the feasibility of introducing a more sophisticated radar instrument which automatically records on film the registration plate numbers and speed of vehicles which travel faster than the speed limit.

    In 1976, 338 lorries were booked for speeding along Jurong Road. In January and February this year, 30 of such lorries have been booked for speeding. It is apparent that more has to be done to instil a sense of road discipline in drivers. Besides more vigorous enforcement, there will be a sustained campaign to educate the drivers on the dangers of speeding and reckless driving.

SERANGOON GARDEN ESTATE
(Request for Police post)


    8. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education if a police post can be located at Serangoon Garden Estate to facilitate contact between the police and the residents.

Column: 819



    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, crime within the Serangoon Garden Estate has been relatively low. The Police therefore has no plans to establish a Police post in the area. Radio Cars and Team Policing Patrol Cars patrol the area daily. All Radio and Team Policing Patrol Cars are equipped with radio communication sets which are linked to Police Radio Division and the Paya Lebar Police Station respectively. In addition, Team Policing Patrol Officers are also equipped with walkie-talkie sets to enable them to communicate with their Divisional Headquarters Station.

SINGAPORE CITIZENSHIP
(Applications from minor citizens)


    9. Mr S. Dhanabalan asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education how many applications for citizenship result from minor citizens who through ignorance fail to take the oath of allegiance on attaining the age of 21 years and whether, instead of calling up such persons and taking away their pink identity cards and issuing them blue identity cards, a procedure can be established to inform such persons individually of the need to take the oath of allegiance and to administer such an oath immediately instead of causing them to join the queue of applicants for citizenship.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, let me state that minors who become Singapore citizens by descent or by registration are required under the Singapore Constitution to take the oath of renunciation, allegiance and loyalty within 12 months on reaching the age of 21 years. Failure to comply with this legal requirement will make them automatically lose their citizenship. It is not possible to reinstate their citizenship once it is lost by reason of non-compliance with this constitutional requirement. Such persons may, however, apply again to be registered as citizens. In 1976, a total of 34 applications were received under this category.

    During the last six years, the number of persons who failed to take the oath and had

Column: 820

lost their citizenship was as follows: 
                           

                      1971 - 135

                      1972 - 150

                      1973 - 122

                      1974 - 84

                      1975 - 86

                      1976 - 67
The figures indicate that the problem is a diminishing one. I also wish to point out that some could have failed to take the oath deliberately for various reasons, such as to evade national service. In 1976, 24 of the 67 who failed to take the oath were known to have done so deliberately.

    It is not practical to send individual reminders to minors about the need to take the oath because many of them were registered as Singapore citizens at a tender age, often below one year old, and it would be extremely difficult to contact these persons, particularly if they are residing overseas and do not possess Singapore identity cards. Even if reminders were to be sent, those who failed to take the oath could always claim that they did not receive the reminders and thus put the blame on the Government for their own failing.

    Nevertheless, the following measures have been taken all along by the Registry of Citizenship to remind minor citizens to take the oath of renunciation, allegiance and loyalty on reaching the age of 21:

    (i) A reminder on the need for the oath taking, in the four official languages, is stamped on the back of all citizenship certificates issued to minor citizens;

    (ii) At the time such certificates are issued, the attention of the parent or guardian is drawn to the oath taking requirement;

    (iii) Singapore passports, both international and restricted, issued to minor citizens are valid only up to their 21st birthday and will not be renewed unless the holders have taken the oath;

    (iv) Since July 1973, a press statement has been issued bi-annually in June and December to remind minor citizens to take

Column: 821

the oath. This statement is carried by the TV, radio and by the newspapers; and

    (v) Minor citizens serving national service in the SAF are also reminded by the SAF to take the oath at the appropriate time.

    The above measures should be sufficient to remind minor citizens to take their oath. If they fail to do so, they have themselves to blame. I might add that citizenship is a serious matter for the minors and their parents to make the effort on their part to remember to take their oath. If they do not, it is an indication that they do not seriously value the citizenship or treat their oath of allegiance to our Republic seriously. They have one full year in which to take their oath.

    Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister mentioned that in 1976 out of the number who failed to take the oath of allegiance, about 34 of them had reapplied. May we know from the Minister how many of these 34 who reapplied were successful, and whether there were any rejections, if so, on what grounds were they rejected?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I have some of the figures here. The majority of those who lost their minor citizenship have reapplied. In 1974, of those who reapplied, 17 were approved; in 1975, 169 were approved; and in 1976, 77 were approved.

    Sir, as some of them are genuine cases of failure to take their oath, they were given sympathetic consideration and, in fact, some of them were given priority consideration. But before approving their citizenship applications, they have to satisfy the various requirements needed. For example, they must have the normal residence of 10 years out of the 12 years preceding their application; that they are of good character and that they have family roots in Singapore.

    Mr S. Dhanabalan (Kallang): Sir, would the Minister please explain why it should be more difficult to send individual reminders when, in fact, individual letters are sent to those who have failed to take their oath of allegiance to exchange their pink identity, cards for blue identity cards?

Column: 822



    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, as I said, the reason is that some of them were registered as minor citizens at the tender age of one year old and have not obtained identity cards at all. If they have identity cards, then it would not be difficult to send them reminders. In fact, the answer to the Member for Kallang's question is contained in the question itself. If they have identity cards, then it would be easier to address them for the return of their identity cards.

    Mr S. Dhanabalan: They must have.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Then it would be easier to address them a letter for the return of their identity cards.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Sir, would the Minister consider withdrawing that part of his reply where he said that those people failed to subscribe to the oath of allegiance for reasons of evasion of national service? Would the Minister consider withdrawing this part of the reply, because there is an apparent contradiction? That is the first question.

    The second question: Is the Minister not aware that the age for national service is set at the age of 18 and that the subscription to the oath of allegiance is at the age of 21? This leads me to the third question. At the age of 21, he would have served national service. So there is an apparent contradiction there. Would the Minister then consider withdrawing his entire reply in the circumstances?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, that statement of mine has been made after very careful thought. I do not know whether the request from the Member for Kampong Chai Chee was made after serious consideration on his part. I am not saying that every one of them did not take the oath because he wanted to evade national service. What I said was "some of them." And it does not mean that when a person has reached the age of 18 he will automatically do national service or, if he has not done national service, he would not have to do national service later. I think it is quite obvious that those people

Column: 823

whom I am referring to are those who have gone abroad at the age of 18 and below and are still abroad. And when they reach the age of 21 they have not returned. This is the category of persons I am referring to.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, is not the Minister therefore implying that those who can afford to go overseas at the age of 18 and before 21 will stand the chance later to deliberately fail to subscribe to the oath of allegiance so as to evade national service? That means those who cannot afford to go overseas have no chance even to say, "I do not want to subscribe to the oath." Is there not a disparity? Would the Minister consider withdrawing this part of his reply?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I just cannot understand the Member for Kampong Chai Chee. I was just referring to a category of people who had not done national service and that they had not done national service because they were not in the country and they had not gone to take the oath of allegiance when they reached the age of 21. That is all that I have said. I am not implying anything further.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, as regards national service registration, it is published in the papers, announced over the radio and TV that everybody affected must register during the stated periods. Why is it, therefore, that minor citizens who reach 21 years of age are not reminded to take the oath?
